sentences.sentence: Last Friday, Toronto Public Health issued an advisory indicating that up 550 patrons of the Brass Rail, a downtown strip club, were potentially exposed to COVID-19.This response was a necessary measure in order to inform the public of their potential risk and to monitor their symptoms while awaiting further guidance.
However, within minutes of this story breaking, people began criticizing the establishment and those who frequent it.

Many suggested that, in our haste to reopen our economy, we had prioritized the wrong businesses, undermined attempts to keep COVID-19 transmission under control and, by extension, worsened our odds of getting children back to school safely in September.While some of this criticism is rooted in a sincere and well-intentioned desire to preserve the safety of our community, it's clear that many individuals have pre-existing biases regarding the relative importance of certain businesses, and they are noticeably heightened during this pandemic.Bars have been much maligned as a source of outbreaks within local communities, and singled out as the trigger for increased incidence of COVID-19 in many other countries, notably the United States, several parts of Europe and Israel, to name only a few.

It is important to note, however, that other businesses have been linked to COVID-19 outbreaks, as well.Fitness centres and gyms, for example, have been associated with several large transmission events.
In comparing the two, fitness centres and bars carry similar risks for COVID-19 transmission.
Both are indoor settings with ventilation challenges and extensive "high-touch" surfaces.
Both involve directing large volumes of occupants and traffic within their respective facilities and, consequently, have the potential for physical distancing measures to fail easily.
Finally, universal masking is a challenge in both environments.Yet despite similar transmission risks, public perception and optics are decidedly different.
Viewed through a moral lens, one institution is designed to promote one's health; the other to imbibe and potentially poison one's liver.
But setting biases aside, it should be acknowledged that both play a role in our society.
Both of these establishments maintain a defined customer base, are legally allowed to operate and contribute to our tax base.

Both employ individuals from our community who may otherwise have little to no means of earning a living.Does a 20-year-old server play a different role in society than a 20-year-old fitness instructor?
Are they not equally deserving of earning an income?
Do they both not warrant the same job stability in the COVID-19 era?
Must they sacrifice their own employment to ensure that children can go to school?Principles of equity should neither be ignored, nor offered tokenistic lip service in our pandemic discourse.

Just as both businesses should require audits, interventions and face repercussions for failing to meet standards for operating safely, so too should those individuals who are dependent on these businesses be afforded the opportunity to earn a living in a safe and legal manner.All businesses, particularly those operating indoors, will be at risk for COVID-19 transmission and outbreaks are inevitable, despite even our best efforts.

However, we would be best served to avoid reactionary responses to these situations.Rather than exercising moral judgment, our efforts would be better invested in investigation, mitigation, management and contact-tracing strategies that are effective and adaptive in their execution.

Businesses that have had success in containing COVID-19 should be looked to as leaders, and public health policy should be agile, so it can adapt to both successes and failures.It should also be noted that the stigmatization and scapegoating of particular consumers or segments of our community will almost certainly hinder accurate and detailed contact-tracing efforts, which are critical to preventing spikes in transmission.

We must engage and educate, rather than judge and alienate.Failure to do so risks inviting more unsafe practices that may not be as easily identified or controlled, thus undermining future efforts to control COVID-19.
Until a proven and effective vaccine is widely available, accountability and trust in one another is our best hope for keeping our communities safe.National PostDr.
Zain Chagla is an associate professor in the department of medicine at McMaster University and an infectious diseases physician in Hamilton, Ont.

Dr. Abdu Sharkawy is an assistant professor in the department of medicine at the University of Toronto and an infectious diseases physician in Toronto.Kelly McParland: Children are paying the price for years of government overspending(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/kelly-mcparland-children-are-paying-the-price-for-years-of-government-overspending/wcm/12ce872f-ff73-4d8e-8911-632630f3e4d9/)Colby Cosh: COVID-19's love of fat(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/colby-cosh-covid-19s-love-of-fat/wcm/0ad9274b-b5a0-4a2f-a0ae-2a39217bacdf/) !

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
